questions.text: What country, state (if relevant), and city are you located in?
questions.prompt_add: Use this location information to provide more accurate and contextually relevant business evaluations. Consider local market conditions, regulations, and business environment specific to this location.

questions.text: Why do you want to sell the business?
questions.prompt_add: Good: planned retirement / succession; Red: urgent cash need, losses, lawsuits, insolvency; Scoring 0-19 critical, 20-49 high, 50-79 moderate, 80-100 low-risk exit

questions.text: How long has the business existed?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 5–20 yrs steady operation; Red: <2 yrs unproven or >30 yrs showing decline; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk longevity

questions.text: Have there been other interested buyers?
questions.prompt_add: Good: documented multiple serious offers or fresh listing with initial inquiries; Red: unverified or conflicting claims, long listing without offers, withdrawn deals; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk interest

questions.text: How do you envision the handover process?
questions.prompt_add: Good: phased handover with documentation and seller support; Red: vague/immediate exit, no docs or assistance; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk transition

questions.text: Would you be willing to support or consult during a transition period?
questions.prompt_add: Good: seller commits to 6–12 mo structured support/training at fair terms; Red: unwilling, token help, or costly fees; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk transition

questions.text: What is the core value the business provides to its customers?
questions.prompt_add: Good: clear value proposition, strong customer relationships; Red: unclear or generic, no competitive advantage; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk differentiation

questions.text: What makes your offering unique or difficult to replicate?
questions.prompt_add: Good: clear value proposition, strong customer relationships; Red: unclear or generic, no competitive advantage; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk differentiation

questions.text: What is your average margin per product/service line?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: What capacity limits or growth constraints does the business face?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: What factors would limit expansion (e.g., staff, licenses, machines)?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: Would a trial takeover (e.g., via lease) be an option?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: Is a reversal or exit clause negotiable in case of failure?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: What safeguards do you suggest for the buyer if the takeover fails?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: What aspects of your operations would you say are "most outdated" or inefficient?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: What were the revenues and profits over the past 3 years?
questions.prompt_add: Good: 10–20% margin, stable pricing, no market pressure; Red: 0–5% margin, price wars, declining margins; Scoring 0–19 critical, 20–49 high, 50–79 moderate, 80–100 low-risk pricing

questions.text: What are the fixed monthly costs (e.g., wages, rent, leasing)?
Are there loans, debts, or leasing contracts in place?
Are there outstanding receivables or unpaid liabilities?
How is pricing calculated? Is there market pressure?
Is the accounting transparent (P&L, BWA, balance sheet)?
Have all tax returns been submitted on time?
Were there any recent tax audits or findings?
Are there personal guarantees or private collateral?
Are there any tax or social security arrears?
Is the business registry entry up to date and correct?
What is the legal structure of the business?
Who holds ownership or shares? Are there silent partners?
Are there intellectual property rights (e.g., patents, trademarks)?
Are there transferable licenses or certifications?
Are there specific industry regulations that apply to the business?
Are there any current or past environmental or regulatory violations?
How many employees do you have, and in what roles?
Are there key personnel with unique expertise?
What is the age distribution of the team?
Has employee turnover been high in recent years?
Are wages competitive in the regional labor market?
What machines or technical equipment does the business use?
What is the condition of the equipment?
Is the equipment owned, leased, or financed?
Are maintenance or service contracts in place?
How is the workspace organized in terms of efficiency?
Are there documented workflows or reliance on informal knowledge?
Do you use digital tools (e.g., ERP, invoicing, time tracking)?
How are quotes, orders, and project documents managed?
Is customer/project data stored digitally and centrally?
How many hours per week does the owner work actively in operations?
Which tasks are currently non-delegable (e.g., pricing, sales)?
What key skills or licenses would a buyer need?
Would external or part-time management be feasible?
Which functions depend solely on the seller?
Is there undocumented knowledge critical to operations?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] Can you describe a typical customer journey — from initial inquiry to final delivery?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] Are there recurring delays, bottlenecks, or capacity constraints?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] How are tasks prioritized and scheduled?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] Do employees follow standardized procedures?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] How often do you reflect on processes to identify improvement potential?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] Are there any visual tools or dashboards used to track ongoing work?
Who are your typical customers (private, business, public)?
Do you have regular or repeat customers?
How are new customers acquired?
What is the current and projected order situation?
What is the company's reputation locally and online?
How strong is your brand (logo, design, recognition)?
What online presence exists (website, social media, domain ownership)?
Is the brand name protected or registered?
Who are your key suppliers and how stable are those relationships?
Are prices fixed or variable? Are there contracts in place?
Are alternative suppliers available?
Are there known risks (legal, economic, operational)?
Is the business dependent on specific customers or suppliers?
What opportunities exist for expansion or innovation?
Are there negative reviews, court cases, or internal conflicts?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] How quickly can you deliver after receiving a customer order?
[Optional – Lean/VSM] What are typical complaints or friction points from customers?
Is the location rented or owned?
How long is the lease valid? Is renewal possible?
Are there relevant contracts with landlords, suppliers, or partners?
Are there any building codes, noise limits, or environmental restrictions?
Are there planned city projects or construction nearby?
How accessible is the location (foot traffic, visibility, roads)?
Are there parking options for customers and deliveries?
Are signage and exterior branding allowed or restricted?
What needs to be handed over (contacts, systems, passwords)?
Is there undocumented or informal knowledge that must be transferred?
Would you support customer introductions or transitions personally?
What insurance policies are in place?
Have they been reviewed recently?
Have there been claims or issues with insurers in the past?
Is the current owner involved in day-to-day operations?
What key tasks are exclusively handled by the owner (e.g., sales, pricing, customer care)?
Is there documentation or delegation of the owner's knowledge and routines?
How many hours per week does the owner actively work in the business?
Are there any succession plans or second-tier management already in place?
Could the business operate for 2+ months without the owner?
How long would a full transition realistically take (in months)?
Are customer relationships owner-bound (personal trust, private networks)?
What reputation or credibility would be lost if the owner exits?
